captions.text: Second Wind

The majority of this video was created 
before Sony pulled that stunt last week with

the mandating Playstation account linking to 
play Helldivers 2. Since the matter warrants

mentioning, it will be addressed in a short 
addendum at the end of this review. Thank you.
[Intro Music]

Ah, I know what you&#39;re thinking. &quot;Yahtzee, 
voluntarily reviewing an online multiplayer game?

Has the seven-headed beast risen from the ocean 
already? Or did every single player game in the

world spontaneously combust last weekend?&quot; Well, 
you&#39;re more likely thinking stuff like &quot;what&#39;s

for lunch,&quot; and &quot;is he really still making these 
videos, talk about peaking too early.&quot; But yes,

unusually for me I&#39;ve been playing Helldivers 
2. Not liking online multiplayer is something

I&#39;ve long come to terms with about myself. I 
prefer games with a rewarding narrative focus,

and live service multiplayer games are usually 
emotionally numbing skinner box grinds,

and let&#39;s not forget that random human beings 
rank slightly lower on my preferred companions

list than an uncontrolled electrical fire. But 
recently I was obliged to play a bit of Helldivers

2 alongside my Second Wind colleagues as part 
of our 12 hour charity stream, so take note,

that&#39;s how you get me to play a live service 
shooter these days: one, for charity, two,

let me do it with my mates so if the stress gets 
too much I can shoot Nick in the face a few times.

Failing that I guess you could try holding 
a gun to the head of one of my loved ones,

but even then I&#39;m gonna need to see 
the calibre before I make a decision.

To my surprise, I had rather a lot of fun playing 
Helldivers 2, which made me suspicious. As I say

I was playing with friends, and &quot;fun with friends&quot; 
is bullshit praise. That just means you like your

friends. Plenty of horrible things in this 
world are fun with friends. Like bad movies,

or pissing on a sleeping cat. But I was 
appreciating Helldivers 2 even when I

wasn&#39;t shooting Nick in the face, I mean, yes, 
it&#39;s a skinner box live service grindathon,

but it doesn&#39;t pretend to be anything else. See, 
other live services like Destiny 2 or any given

MMORPG, always present themselves with a certain 
big-bollocked lack of self-awareness. You are the

hero, you are fighting the important fight, gosh, 
I can scarcely get past you in the corridor with

the sheer bigness of your bollocks, but that 
never comes across while actually playing the

game. While playing the game I feel like a 
single ineffectual frozen pea in a great big

bag of frozen peas, most of which are bigger 
and have better gear, and completing missions

doesn&#39;t feel like I&#39;m achieving anything 
that isn&#39;t getting instantly reversed.

All of that is still true of Helldivers 2, but 
the difference is, it makes sense in context,

too. The game kicks off with a very 
Starship Troopers-inspired - ooh,

if I minced these words any harder I could top 
it with mashed potato and call it cottage pie.

It literally is Starship Troopers, okay? 
A totalitarian future Earth fighting a

high-tech war against alien bugs on a distant 
planet we&#39;ve got no more business on than does

a double decker bus in a swimming pool, 
using bombastic state media to blind its

citizens with promises of glory and appeals to 
patriotism so it can have a neverending supply

of dumb recruits to throw into the meat grinder. 
&quot;Rip off&quot; is a harsh phrase but you know what,

considering the irony of Starship Troopers went 
over so many people&#39;s heads the first time,

probably wouldn&#39;t hurt to give it a second 
crack. So you go through about ten minutes

of training in which you shoot some aliens that 
have essentially been pinned to the floor, get

massively overpraised by a prerecorded voice then 
shot into space in the hope you&#39;ll actually take

out a few of the fuckers before they dissemble 
your protein for the brood maggots. But this

is where we deviate a little from the Starship 
Troopers template, because when you arrive the

game goes &quot;Hi! Here&#39;s a free spaceship just for 
you. Go join a battle. It doesn&#39;t matter which.&quot;

While Starship Troopers is about a fascist state 
instigating forever war as a way to control its

own population, Helldivers feels more like 
what happens when human society has run out

of shit to do. Clearly there&#39;s no scarcity if 
they&#39;re handing out free spaceships and can

drop limitless amounts of ammo and airstrikes 
for any random soldier with enough remaining

fingers to work a touchtone phone, apparently the 
human race is now just roaming the galaxy picking

fights for want of something to do, achieving 
bugger all of consequence except for killing

all the buggers. Feels weird to say, but I guess 
my tolerance for live service grinds increases

when I feel like the story isn&#39;t bullshitting me. 
Thanks, Helldivers 2, in return I won&#39;t bullshit

you. I&#39;m going to play your Skinner box grindathon 
gameplay with a podcast on to keep my brain alive,

please extend my apologies to your music composers 
and voice actors who spent all that time in

the studio trying to convincingly scream like 
they&#39;re getting impaled on a pedipalp. Pedipaled,

perhaps. And as a Skinner box grindathon 
Helldivers 2 will certainly do the job.

You get inserted into an open-ended map with a 
buffet of objectives to complete before making

for the extraction point while getting harassed 
by endlessly respawning enemies, and I quickly

learned that relying exclusively on the guns 
you carry with you is an excellent way to have

to spend every evening picking antennae out of 
your bumhole, and a smart player relies on calling

down airstrikes and support weapons with a rather 
neat little dial-a-war-crime system that creates

very effective moments of panicky desperation 
as you attempt to calmly enter the code number

for an orbital strike while fencing a forest of 
slashing monster claws with your one good leg.

So at first I was trying to see if Helldivers 
2 works as a single player game. Short answer,

no. Short, profane answer, fuck no. Oh, you can 
certainly start a mission by yourself with random

pubbies blocked but like an Alzheimer&#39;s patient at 
a bukkake shoot you won&#39;t be able to get anything

achieved before getting blindsided by another 
dick. I tried dropping the difficulty down to

easy once I&#39;d found a spare dummy to suck on, but 
the eventual mission rewards were so insultingly

small it felt like being given a nem-nem for 
going poo-poos in the toilet like mummy asked.

And saving up to buy a new cape with two 
stripes instead of one isn&#39;t much of a way

to track progress but it&#39;s all we&#39;ve fucking got. 
So I held my nose and tried playing with pubbies,

and swiftly learned that the other thing to be 
said for playing with friends is that your friends

actually talk to you, saying things like &quot;enemies 
to the west&quot; and &quot;please stop shooting Nick in

the face.&quot; Pubbies, meanwhile, are here to make 
premium currency, not social connections, and will

fall into one of three categories: the massively 
higher level twat who runs off to complete all

the side objectives by themselves with their fancy 
pants high level airstrikes with rear spoilers and

fuzzy dice, the clueless twat who keeps calling 
down airstrikes right on my previous body I&#39;m

desperately trying to recover my decent equipment 
from, and the furious twat who keeps shooting me

in retaliation for calling down airstrikes 
on their previous body they&#39;re desperately

trying to etc. So I doubt I&#39;ll play any more 
Helldivers 2 in my spare time, but damn it if

I don&#39;t appreciate the tightness of its design and 
the degree of immersion storytelling that conveys

its intended themes through gameplay. Namely that 
human beings suck ass, massacring aliens in their

own environment is stupid and really hard, and 
Nick&#39;s face makes very amusing noises when shot.
SHAME THEY FUCKED IT UP
